The CLARITY Act focuses specifically on market structure and regulatory jurisdiction, while other proposals like the Lummis-Gillibrand bill take a more comprehensive approach covering multiple aspects of digital asset regulation. Q5: What are the potential impacts if this bill becomes law? title: Bitcoin As Bonus: Steak ’n Shake Rolls Out BTC Pay Perks For Workers
body: American fast food chain Steak ‘n Shake has announced that all hourly employees will receive a Bitcoin bonus starting on March 1st. Steak ‘n Shake Integrates Bitcoin Bonus Payments Steak ‘n Shake will pay all hourly employees at its company-operated restaurants a bonus in Bitcoin for every hour of work, as revealed by the company’s official X handle . Steak ‘n Shake, primarily based in the United States, is a fast food chain that mainly serves burgers and milkshakes, with its flagship item being the Steakburger. Back in May 2025, the firm opened itself to Bitcoin, allowing customers to pay at all its locations using the cryptocurrency. Last Friday, Steak ‘n Shake provided an update on the scheme, noting that same-store sales have dramatically increased for the company since it started accepting BTC. The firm added that all of its BTC sales go into its Strategic Bitcoin Reserve (SBR) and announced that it expanded this reserve by an additional $10 million in notional value in that same update. “We have created a self-sustaining system — growing same-store sales that grow the SBR,” wrote the company. “Improving food quality expands Steak n Shake’s reach and leverages Bitcoin into a new and delicious dimension.” Now, it seems Steak ‘n Shake has taken its BTC acceptance a step further with the employee bonus integration. According to the announcement, all hourly employees will receive $0.21 BTC for every hour worked. However, only workers who have passed a two-year vesting period will be able to collect their digital asset pay. Steak ‘n Shake credited Fold for providing assistance on the initiative. Fold is a financial services platform that offers, among other features, a debit card allowing users to earn BTC rewards on payments. The Bitcoin bonus program is set to go live on March 1st. “We take care of our employees; they, in turn, take care of customers; and the results take care of themselves,” said Steak ‘n Shake. title: Is Bitcoin Selling Off On Quantum Fears? A Reality Check
body: Bitcoin’s Tuesday slide to $87,895 has revived a familiar market habit: attaching a single, clean narrative to messy positioning, flows, and reflexive price action. This time, the culprit making the rounds is quantum computing, a potentially “existential threat” that’s supposedly explaining Bitcoin’s underperformance versus gold which has printed a new all-time high at $4,888. The quantum angle picked up steam after a post by Nic Carter, a partner at Castle Island Ventures. Carter wrote: “Bitcoin’s “mysterious” underperformance (due to quantum) is the only story that matters this year. The market is speaking the devs aren’t listening,” and shared a tweet about the news that Wall Street strategist Christopher Wood removed a 10% Bitcoin allocation from a model portfolio due to concerns that quantum computing could undermine Bitcoin’s long-term value proposition. Is Bitcoin Falling On Quantum Fears? Not everyone buying the premise is buying the price-action conclusion. Well-known Bitcoin advocate Vijay Boyapati, while acknowledging quantum computing as a real issue, pushed back on using it as the primary explanation for why Bitcoin is stalling and selling off. Related Reading: Bitcoin Whale Panic Fades: Sell Pressure On Binance Falls Off A Cliff “While I agree QC is a legitimate concern… I think the price stalling invites narratives to fill the explanatory void when, imo, the real explanation is really just the unlocking of an enormous supply once we hit a magic number for a lot of whales (100k),” Boyapati wrote. “Prices increasing are like waves hitting a glacier – eventually a chunk of supply breaks off and crashes onto the order books.” Boyapati’s broader point is that market structure can do plenty of damage on its own once a big level triggers distribution and confidence cracks. “Given the path dependent nature and feedback loops involved in a bull run sustained on narratives… the price stalling then causes people to doubt that Bitcoin will continue to go up and this then results in more selling until you get an equilibrium of supply and demand at some lower price point,” he added. “This is what happens during Bitcoin bear markets – and I think we’re in one.” James Check, a prominent Bitcoin on-chain analyst, co-founder of Check on Chain, and former Lead Analyst at Glassnode, largely sided with the view that quantum risk may be a background constraint on some capital, but not the dominant driver of the gold-versus-Bitcoin divergence. Related Reading: Tom Lee Still Sees Bitcoin At $250,000 But Warns 2026 Gets ‘Jagged’ “QC keeps some capital away, but this argument that gold is up and Bitcoin is down because of it just isn’t it,” he wrote. “Gold has a bid because sovereigns are buying it in place of treasuries. The trend has been in place since 2008, and accelerates after Feb-22.” He also highlighted the supply-side pressure Bitcoin has already absorbed. “Bitcoin saw sell-side from HODLers in 2025 which would have killed every prior bull thrice over, and then once more,” Checkmate said. The policy takeaway, in his view, is practical but limited: quantum preparedness matters, but attributing every downturn to it doesn’t help traders understand what’s actually clearing the market. In a short market update posted via Checkmate’s analytics brand Checkonchain, the immediate trigger for the move was described in leverage terms rather than existential risk. Bitcoin “sold back down into the high $80ks,” with “the bears taking a bunch of leveraged long traders out to the woodshed,” the note said, estimating that around $260 million in leveraged long exposure was wiped. Technically, the desk framed the structure as still resembling a bear flag, with a “clear supply air-pocket” between $70,000 and $81,000, language that points to thin bid support if sellers regain control. title: Maroo Blockchain Revolutionizes KRW Stablecoin with Groundbreaking Hybrid Architecture
body: BitcoinWorld Maroo Blockchain Revolutionizes KRW Stablecoin with Groundbreaking Hybrid Architecture SEOUL, South Korea – December 2024 – In a significant development for Asia’s cryptocurrency landscape, blockchain investment firm Hashed has unveiled Maroo, a revolutionary blockchain platform specifically engineered for a Korean won-backed stablecoin. This strategic launch represents a pivotal moment for South Korea’s digital finance sector, potentially bridging the gap between traditional banking systems and decentralized blockchain technology. The Maroo blockchain announcement comes amid growing global interest in central bank digital currencies and regulated stablecoin frameworks. Maroo Blockchain Architecture and Technical Innovation Hashed’s Maroo blockchain introduces a novel hybrid architecture that combines the openness and scalability of public chains with the regulatory compliance and privacy features demanded by traditional financial institutions. According to technical documentation reviewed by industry analysts, the platform employs a permissioned layer that interfaces with regulatory bodies while maintaining a public layer for transparent transaction verification. This dual-layer approach addresses one of the most persistent challenges in blockchain adoption by financial institutions: balancing transparency requirements with privacy concerns. The platform’s transaction fee mechanism represents another significant innovation. Unlike most blockchain networks that require users to hold and spend a native cryptocurrency for transaction fees, Maroo allows users to pay fees directly with the KRW stablecoin. This user-friendly feature eliminates the complexity of managing multiple tokens and reduces barriers to entry for mainstream adoption. Furthermore, the network’s consensus mechanism reportedly incorporates energy-efficient validation protocols, addressing environmental concerns associated with earlier blockchain generations. The country’s Financial Services Commission has been progressively developing comprehensive cryptocurrency regulations since the 2021 Virtual Asset User Protection Act. Recent amendments to the Electronic Financial Transactions Act now provide clearer guidelines for stablecoin issuance and operation. These regulatory developments create a more predictable environment for projects like Maroo to operate within established legal frameworks. South Korea’s interest in digital currency innovation extends beyond private sector initiatives. The Bank of Korea has been actively researching a central bank digital currency (CBDC) since 2020, completing its first phase of testing in 2022. While the central bank maintains a cautious approach toward full CBDC implementation, private sector solutions like Maroo could serve as complementary systems that address specific use cases not covered by a potential future CBDC. Industry observers note that Maroo’s design appears to anticipate potential integration pathways with both existing banking infrastructure and future national digital currency systems. Market Context and Competitive Positioning The Korean won stablecoin market represents a significant opportunity given South Korea’s status as one of the world’s most active cryptocurrency trading nations. Despite this activity, the local market has lacked a dominant, regulated KRW-pegged stablecoin solution. Existing approaches have typically involved offshore dollar-pegged stablecoins or limited domestic offerings with restricted functionality. Maroo enters this landscape with several competitive advantages: Regulatory Alignment: Designed specifically for South Korea’s regulatory framework Technical Integration: Native support for Korean financial infrastructure User Experience: Simplified fee structure using the stablecoin itself Institutional Focus: Features catering to traditional financial entities Hashed Open Finance and Broader Strategic Vision Hashed has established a dedicated subsidiary, Hashed Open Finance, to advance projects in stablecoins, real-world asset (RWA) tokenization, and security token offerings (STOs) within South Korea. This organizational structure reflects a strategic commitment to regulated digital asset innovation. The subsidiary will reportedly focus on three primary areas: developing compliant financial products, establishing partnerships with traditional financial institutions, and creating educational resources for institutional adoption. The real-world asset tokenization component represents a particularly significant growth area. South Korea’s substantial real estate market, estimated at over $6 trillion, presents enormous potential for fractional ownership through tokenization. Similarly, the country’s vibrant art and collectibles market could benefit from blockchain-based provenance tracking and fractional investment opportunities. Hashed Open Finance’s initiatives in this space align with global trends toward asset tokenization while addressing local regulatory requirements and market characteristics. Expansion Plans and Multi-Currency Framework While Maroo’s initial focus remains the Korean won, Hashed has announced plans to expand the platform to support other fiat currencies in alignment with local regulations. This multi-currency approach could position Maroo as a regional solution for Asian digital currency markets. The expansion strategy reportedly involves establishing separate legal entities and compliance frameworks for each jurisdiction, rather than attempting a one-size-fits-all global approach. This localized methodology acknowledges the significant regulatory diversity across Asian markets while maintaining technical consistency across implementations. The planned expansion follows a phased approach: Phase 1 (2024-2025): KRW stablecoin launch and domestic ecosystem development Phase 2 (2026): Expansion to select Asian markets with regulatory clarity Phase 3 (2027+): Broader international deployment based on regulatory developments Institutional Adoption Pathways and Banking Integration Maroo’s design specifically addresses requirements for traditional financial institution adoption. The platform incorporates features that facilitate integration with existing banking systems, including API standards compatible with South Korea’s financial technology infrastructure. Early discussions with domestic banks suggest interest in several potential use cases, including cross-border remittances, trade finance automation, and interbank settlement efficiency improvements. Industry analysts identify several factors that could accelerate institutional adoption: Regulatory Clarity: South Korea’s progressive stance on cryptocurrency regulation Technical Compatibility: Maroo’s design for banking system integration Market Demand: Growing institutional interest in blockchain solutions Competitive Pressure: Global developments in digital currency infrastructure Security Considerations and Risk Management As with any financial infrastructure project, security represents a paramount concern. Maroo’s architecture reportedly incorporates multiple security layers, including formal verification of smart contracts, multi-signature transaction requirements for large transfers, and regular third-party security audits. The platform’s compliance features also include transaction monitoring capabilities that can interface with anti-money laundering (AML) and know-your-customer (KYC) systems used by financial institutions. These security and compliance measures aim to address concerns that have previously limited blockchain adoption in regulated financial applications. Conclusion The Maroo blockchain represents a sophisticated approach to digital currency infrastructure that balances innovation with regulatory compliance. Hashed’s platform addresses specific challenges in the Korean financial market while establishing a template for regulated blockchain adoption more broadly. The project’s success will depend on multiple factors, including continued regulatory cooperation, institutional adoption rates, and technical performance under real-world conditions. Nevertheless, Maroo’s launch marks an important milestone in the evolution of blockchain technology from speculative applications toward regulated financial infrastructure. The platform’s focus on the KRW stablecoin and real-world asset tokenization reflects growing recognition that blockchain’s most significant impact may come through integration with traditional financial systems rather than complete replacement. title: Crypto Projects: Solana Founder Reveals Three Essential Principles to Attract Capital Successfully
body: BitcoinWorld Crypto Projects: Solana Founder Reveals Three Essential Principles to Attract Capital Successfully In a significant development for blockchain entrepreneurs, Solana co-founder Anatoly Yakovenko has revealed three fundamental principles that early-stage crypto projects must implement to successfully attract capital in today’s competitive market. His insights, shared via social media platform X, arrive during a pivotal moment for cryptocurrency funding as investors grow increasingly discerning about tokenomics and long-term viability. These guidelines emerge from Yakovenko’s extensive experience building one of blockchain’s most successful ecosystems, offering practical wisdom for founders navigating the complex landscape of crypto venture funding. Solana Founder’s Three Principles for Capital Attraction Anatoly Yakovenko’s framework provides specific, actionable advice for cryptocurrency projects seeking investment. First, he emphasizes that projects must ensure staking mechanisms exist for long-term holders. This approach creates immediate utility for tokens while aligning investor incentives with network security. Second, Yakovenko recommends unlocking more than 20% of the token supply on launch day. This substantial initial availability prevents artificial scarcity that often leads to volatile price swings and community distrust. Third, he advocates for fully vesting investor allocations after one year rather than employing extended multi-year schedules that can create persistent selling pressure. Industry analysts immediately recognized the significance of these recommendations. “Yakovenko’s principles address the most common pitfalls in crypto project design,” noted blockchain economist Dr. Marcus Chen in a recent interview. “Projects that ignore these fundamentals often struggle with community alignment and sustainable growth.” Historical data supports this perspective: projects with less than 20% initial token unlocks experienced 40% higher volatility in their first six months according to CryptoFund Research’s 2024 analysis. The Critical Role of Tokenomics in Project Success Token distribution mechanics fundamentally influence a cryptocurrency project’s ability to attract and retain capital. Yakovenko’s emphasis on substantial initial unlocks contrasts with earlier industry practices that favored minimal circulating supplies. This evolution reflects maturing market understanding about sustainable token economics. Projects like Solana itself demonstrated the effectiveness of balanced distribution, with approximately 23% of SOL tokens circulating at its 2020 launch. Staking availability represents another crucial consideration for attracting capital. “Long-term holders seek both yield and governance participation,” explained venture capitalist Samantha Reyes of Blockchain Capital Partners. “Projects without staking mechanisms often fail to retain institutional interest beyond initial speculation.” The data substantiates this claim: staking-enabled projects secured 65% more follow-on funding in 2024 according to industry reports. This concept, borrowed from traditional technology entrepreneurship, refers to creating a product that satisfies strong market demand. In cryptocurrency contexts, PMF means solving genuine problems with blockchain technology rather than implementing solutions in search of problems. “Tokenomics can attract initial capital, but only genuine utility sustains projects,” Yakovenko noted in his original statement. Recent blockchain history illustrates this principle clearly. Projects with strong tokenomics but weak PMF averaged just 14 months of operation before significant devaluation, while those with both elements demonstrated sustained growth. The Solana ecosystem itself provides compelling evidence: its combination of technical innovation (high throughput, low costs) with thoughtful token distribution created conditions for remarkable expansion. Since 2020, Solana has processed over 100 billion transactions while maintaining active developer engagement exceeding 2,500 monthly contributors. Evolution of Crypto Funding Standards The cryptocurrency investment landscape has matured significantly since Bitcoin’s early days. Initially, projects attracted capital primarily through technical whitepapers and community enthusiasm. However, multiple market cycles have taught investors to evaluate fundamentals more rigorously. Yakovenko’s principles reflect this evolution toward institutional-grade standards. Venture firms now employ dedicated tokenomics analysts who assess distribution schedules, inflation mechanisms, and governance structures alongside traditional metrics like team experience and technology differentiation. This professionalization has created clearer pathways for quality projects. “We’ve moved from speculative mania to fundamental analysis,” observed investment strategist Lina Park of Digital Asset Advisors. “Yakovenko’s guidelines articulate what sophisticated investors have been evaluating internally for several years.” The shift manifests in funding patterns: in 2024, projects with transparent, balanced tokenomics secured 3.2 times more capital than those with opaque or extractive models. For example, layer-2 scaling solutions might implement different staking mechanics than decentralized social media platforms. “The principles provide a framework, not a prescription,” emphasized blockchain consultant David Miller. “Founders must understand their unique value proposition and community needs when designing token economics.” This nuanced application explains why projects with similar tokenomics can experience divergent outcomes based on execution quality and market timing. Conclusion Anatoly Yakovenko’s three principles for attracting capital offer cryptocurrency founders a proven framework grounded in Solana’s remarkable success story. By ensuring staking availability for long-term holders, unlocking substantial token supplies initially, and implementing reasonable investor vesting, projects can build the foundation for sustainable growth. However, as Yakovenko emphasizes, these mechanics alone cannot guarantee success. Ultimately, achieving genuine product-market fit remains the essential requirement for any blockchain project seeking lasting impact and value creation. As the cryptocurrency ecosystem continues maturing, these guidelines will likely become standard evaluation criteria for investors and founders alike, separating serious projects from speculative ventures in an increasingly competitive landscape. title: Solana Policy Institute President’s Top Priorities For CLARITY Act And Latest Update On The Bill
body: As discussions surrounding the CLARITY Act—often referred to as the crypto market structure bill—continue in Washington, Kristin Smith, President of the Solana Policy Institute, has provided insights on the current status of the legislation and the organization’s top priorities . Solana Policy Institute’s Optimism For CLARITY Act One of the main priorities disclosed by Smith in a recent post on social media platform X (formerly Twitter), is the importance of protecting open-source developers in the legislative landscape. Smith pointed out that the recent delay in the markup of the market structure bill last week after Coinbase’s withdrawal should be seen as a temporary setback. “Despite the delay, industry engagement remains robust, and there is clear bipartisan support to achieve durable regulatory clarity for market structure,” she noted. The Senate Agriculture Committee is making advancements with its own draft of the legislation expected to be released on Wednesday, as earlier reported by Bitcoinist. Smith also highlighted a shared objective: to create a framework that protects consumers, fosters innovation, and provides certainty for developers operating in the United States. A central tenet of this goal is the safeguarding of developers, which Smith argued is crucial for the success of the industry. Smith Advocates For Developer Protections The Solana Institute was founded to ensure that policymakers gain a comprehensive understanding of public blockchains and the protocols that underpin them. Smith articulated the critical role that open-source software plays within the crypto ecosystem , noting that developers around the world collaborate to produce software that anyone can inspect, use, or improve. “Openness is a strength—not a liability,” she asserted. However, she raised concerns regarding the case against Roman Storm of Tornado Cash, indicating that it treats open-source innovation as something questionable. Smith warned that penalizing developers merely for writing and publishing open-source code endangers all those involved in such collaborative efforts. She emphasized the “chilling effect” that the prosecution could have on open-source developers , asserting that writing code is an expressive act protected by the First Amendment. Smith called for clear policy that differentiates between bad actors and developers working on lawful, general-purpose tools. To bolster this cause, she encouraged supporters to draft letters expressing their stance in favor of open-source protections. Roman Storm responded to Smith’s support, thanking her and the broader community for advocating for open-source principles. He remarked, “Criminalizing the act of writing and publishing code threatens not just one developer, but the foundations of digital security, privacy, and innovation.” At the time of writing, Solana’s native token, SOL, was trading at $130.33, mirroring the performance of the broader crypto market, dropping 11% in the weekly time frame. title: White House Crypto Czar says banks and crypto will merge into one industry
body: The White House AI and Crypto Czar, David Sacks, shared his belief that a point will come when banks and crypto firms will join forces to form a single digital asset industry. According to him, this move will be observed as soon as the long-awaited market structure bill receives a go-ahead from Congress. Sacks released this statement during an interview on CNBC’s Squawk Box. Notably, this interview coincided with the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, which was held on Wednesday, January 21. Sacks’ comments come as banks have launched a last-minute lobbying push to protect their margins and limit competition by blocking crypto from replicating their business model. They are attempting to insert new language into the Clarity Act , stablecoin legislation that the crypto industry has supported for months, to close this potential loophole. In its final lobbying disclosure for 2025, the American Bankers Association—the main trade group for the banking industry—reported spending over $2 million, including efforts related to the Clarity Act. Sacks argued that the crypto industry should support the CLARITY Act to be approved soon Following Sacks’ remarks , reporters reached out to the US official to request a comment on the progress of the proposed CLARITY Act, which has been postponed amid heated debate over whether it is wise to allow stablecoin issuers to provide yield. In response to this request, the crypto leader began by admitting that the ongoing debate is stalling the legislation. Afterwards, Sacks called on lawmakers, banks, and crypto companies to find common ground to pass the market structure bill and send it to US President Donald Trump for a signature to become law. However, he pointed out that he was not shocked to see the bill facing hardships, arguing that the GENIUS Act also encountered several challenges but later became law. Still, the crypto leader released a statement addressed to banks, claiming that they need to understand that yield is already accounted for in current legislation. For the crypto industry as a whole, Sacks urged a broader, strategic view of the current situation, asserting that getting the market structure bill approved is just as crucial as yield and that it should be the industry’s main focus. To break this point down, he mentioned that, “Once this bill passes, banks will fully enter the crypto field. We won’t have separate banking and crypto sectors; instead, there will be one digital asset industry. Over time, banks will appreciate offering yield since they’ll be involved in stablecoins.” Uncertainties surround the CLARITY Act Debates between traditional banks and crypto firms over whether it is advisable to permit stablecoins to earn interest have heated up for several months now. Last week, the situation intensified when Coinbase announced it would drop support for the CLARITY Act. This was after Brian Armstrong, CEO of Coinbase, shared an X post claiming that, “there were too many problems with the current version of the bill, including its aim to stop stablecoins from offering yields while protecting banks from competition.” At this moment, banks cautioned that if, by any chance, stablecoins receive the go-ahead to offer high interest rates, individuals exploring the crypto sector might be forced to shift their focus away from traditional bank accounts. This move is set to bring about significant losses from low-interest savings accounts. Meanwhile, it is worth noting that after the United States GENIUS Act was approved in July 2025, the bill halted token issuers from providing stablecoin yields.
